title: Intro to ref()
summary: See how ref() stitches staging layers into a mart model.

title: Lesson 1 - A dbt model is just SQL
summary: Edit a plain SELECT to see dbt models are just files.

title: Lesson 2 - Why ref() exists
summary: Replace hardcoded tables with ref() so dbt can see dependencies.

title: Lesson 3 - Dependencies create build order
summary: Refs alone tell dbt which models must build first.

title: Lesson 4 - What dbt learns from your SQL
summary: See the metadata dbt captures before it runs anything.

title: Module Capstone - Make dbt see this model
summary: Fix the broken model with ref() so lineage shows both inputs.

title: Module 2 Lesson 1 - Why staging models exist
summary: See why raw data flows into staging first.

title: Module 2 Lesson 2 - Staging models are boring on purpose
summary: Consistency matters more than clever SQL here.

title: Module 2 Lesson 3 - Intermediate models reduce cognitive load
summary: Join staging models together before adding business context.

title: Module 2 Lesson 4 - Marts represent business concepts
summary: Aggregate clean inputs into a business-facing table.

title: Module 2 Lesson 5 - Layers help people reason about change
summary: Raw â†’ staging â†’ intermediate â†’ mart keeps change understandable.

title: Module 3 Lesson 1 - What a materialization is
summary: Understand that configs change what dbt creates, not the SQL.

title: Module 3 Lesson 2 - View vs table
summary: Compare how dbt would create a view versus a table.

title: Module 3 Lesson 3 - Incremental models
summary: See how incremental models think in first run vs later runs.

title: Incremental materializations (advanced)
summary: Why incremental models need guards and unique keys.

title: Module 3 Lesson 4 - Ephemeral models
summary: Highlight that ephemeral models organise SQL without storing data.

title: Module 3 Lesson 5 - Choosing materializations is about intent
summary: Match layers (staging, intermediate, marts) to conceptual materializations.

title: Module 4 Lesson 1 - What a test really is
summary: Treat tests as questions about your data.

title: Module 4 Lesson 2 - Tests live next to models
summary: See how assumptions stay with the model.

title: Module 4 Lesson 3 - Why documentation exists
summary: Pair descriptions with SQL for clarity.

title: Module 4 Lesson 4 - Exposures connect models to usage
summary: Map models to dashboards and notebooks.

title: Module 4 Lesson 5 - Glue, not features
summary: Combine tests, docs, and exposures.

title: Module 5 Lesson 1 - Current vs historical state
summary: See why most models only show today.

title: Module 5 Lesson 2 - Why change matters
summary: Think about how values shift over time.

title: Module 5 Lesson 3 - What a snapshot represents
summary: Snapshots remember what used to be true and when.

title: Module 5 Lesson 4 - Snapshots are not models
summary: Compare current-state models vs historical snapshots.

title: Module 5 Lesson 5 - When to reach for snapshots
summary: Only reach for snapshots when history matters.

title: Module 6 Lesson 1 - dbt builds a graph
summary: See how dbt thinks in nodes and dependencies.

title: Module 6 Lesson 2 - What dbt learns from models
summary: Inspect metadata without running SQL.

title: Module 6 Lesson 3 - Different object types
summary: Models, snapshots, tests, and exposures share the graph.

title: Module 6 Lesson 4 - Why compilation exists
summary: Compilation produces the manifest dbt needs.

title: Module 6 Lesson 5 - From mental model to projects
summary: Understanding the internal graph removes the mystery.
